facts.text: Property in dispute belonged to Wadhawa Singh, father of the respondent.

facts.text: Wadhawa Singh died in 1933.

facts.text: Appellants filed suit as reversioners questioning the 1933 gift.

facts.text: Appellants filed suit for possession alleging second gift void.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then filed the suit, out of which this appeal arises, for possession of the lands alleging that the second gift was void.

arguments.claim: Second gift by widow is void because she was not in possession of the property and thus did not become full owner under Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act

anchor.surface_text: Had not the widow made the gift to the respondent in 1933, she would have become an absolute owner of the property as a result of S. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act and the gift made by her subsequently in favour of the respondent could not have been questioned. But having made the gift in 1933 she was not in possession of the property inherited by her from her husband and, therefore, did not become a full owner, with the result that the subsequent gift made by her in favour of the respondent was of no effect.

arguments.claim: Unless the limited owner is in possession of the property, Section 14 does not apply

anchor.surface_text: This point that unless the limited owner is in possession of the property section 14 does not apply has now been settled by decisions of this Court beyond dispute.

arguments.claim: Previous suit decree is res judicata; respondent cannot dispute custom applicability or circumstances

anchor.surface_text: It is not now open to the respondent to show whether any of the circumstances mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) of paragraph 23 of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law is present here as the previous decision is res judicata between the parties and in any case it has not been attempted to be shown in this case.

holdings.text: The widow did not become a full owner under Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act because she was not in possession of the property after the 1933 gift, rendering the subsequent gift to the respondent of no effect.

anchor.surface_text: Had not the widow made the gift to the respondent in 1933, she would have become an absolute owner of the property as a result of S. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act and the gift made by her subsequently in favour of the respondent could not have been questioned. But having made the gift in 1933 she was not in possession of the property inherited by her from her husband and, therefore, did not become a full owner, with the result that the subsequent gift made by her in favour of the respondent was of no effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior invalid gift deprived widow of possession required for S.14 to confer absolute ownership; settled by prior Supreme Court decisions.

holdings.text: Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act does not apply unless the limited owner is in possession of the property.

anchor.surface_text: This point that unless the limited owner is in possession of the property section 14 does not apply has now been settled by decisions of this Court beyond dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly settled by binding Supreme Court precedents.

holdings.text: The provisions of Section 8 of the Hindu Succession Act are not retrospective in operation and have no application where succession opened before the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the provisions of s. 8 of the Hindu Succession Act are not retrospective in operation and where a male Hindu died before the Act came into force i.e., where succession opened before the Act s. 8 of the Act will have no application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Eramma v. Verrupanna and textual contrast with S.6; harmonious construction.

holdings.text: Succession to the estate opens on the death of the limited owner (widow), and is governed by the law in force at that time.

anchor.surface_text: during the lifetime of the widow, the reversioners in Hindu Law have no vested interest in the estate but have a mere spes successionis or chance of succession,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reversioners have only spes successionis; per Privy Council precedents (Moniram Kolita, Duni Chand); legal fiction requires applying consequences of fictional death under then-current law.

holdings.text: Section 8 of the Hindu Succession Act applies to determine succession where the male Hindu died before the Act but the intervening limited owner (widow) died after, as succession opens on the widow's death.

anchor.surface_text: What then is the effect of the provision of s. 8 of the Hindu Succession Act in the circumstances of this case. The Punjab High Court in its decisions in Banso v. Charan Singh

holdings.reasoning_summary: Succession opens on widow's death per established Hindu law; S.8 governs prospectively; distinguishes Eramma and conflicting High Courts; approves Punjab HC view.

holdings.text: In the present case, succession to Wadhawa Singh's estate opened on his widow's death in 1963 and is governed by Section 8 of the Hindu Succession Act, under which the daughter succeeds in preference to the reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: succession to Wadhawa Singhs estate in the present case opened when his widow died and it would have to, be decided on the basis that Wadhawa Singh had died in 1963 when his widow died. In that case the succession to his estate would have to, be decided on the basis of s.8 of the Hindu Succession Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying general principle to facts; HSA overrides prior custom; second gift void but estate passes to daughter as Class I heir under S.8.

holdings.text: The decision in Eramma v. Verrupanna does not govern cases where succession reopens on death of limited owner after the Act.

anchor.surface_text: But it should be noticed that the problem that we are faced with in the present appeal and in the cases before the Punjab and Mysore High Courts did not arise before this Court on the earlier occasion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eramma did not consider reopening of succession on limited owner's death; different facts (no limited owner intervening).

holdings.text: Under pre-HSA Punjab Customary Law, a daughter succeeds to ancestral property only in default of specified heirs and near male collaterals, absent specified circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt about the position under the Customary Law of Punjab before coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act. In Rattigans Digest of the Customary Law published by the University Book Agency 14th Ed., paragraph 23 at page 132 it is stated 23.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded based on authoritative text (Rattigan's Digest) and prior precedents; but HSA now governs.

holdings.text: The decree in the prior suit is res judicata, binding the parties; respondent cannot now dispute applicability of custom or presence of exceptions favoring daughter.

anchor.surface_text: It is not now open to the respondent to show whether any of the circumstances mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) of paragraph 23 of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law is present here as the previous decision is resjudicata between the parties and in any case it has not been attempted to be shown in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior suit decreed gift invalid as reversioners; respondent party thereto; bars relitigation.

precedents.cited_proposition: a widow who succeeds to the estate of her husband does not take a mere life-estate in the property [...] the succession does not open to the heirs of the husband until the termination of the widows estate. anchor.surface_text: Had not the widow made the gift to the respondent in 1933, she would have become an absolute owner of the property as a result of S. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act and the gift made by her subsequently in favour of the respondent could not have been questioned. But having made the gift in 1933 she was not in possession of the property inherited by her from her husband and, therefore, did not become a full owner, with the result that the subsequent gift made by her in favour of the respondent was of no effect.

Thus two propositions follow 1 Succession opens on- the death of the limited owner. and 2 the law then in force would govern the succession. Now if this proposition is correct, as we hold it is, that where a female heir succeeds to an estate, the person entitled to succeed on the basis as if the last male holder had lived up to and died at the Mt. Rajpali Kunwer v. Surju Rai 58 All. 1041 . Shakuntala Devi v. Kambsalya Devi 17 Lah 356 .

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the provisions of s. 8 of the Hindu Succession Act are not retrospective in operation and where a male Hindu died before the Act came into force i.e., where succession opened before the Act s. 8 of the Act will have no application.

Thus two propositions follow 1 Succession opens on- the death of the limited owner. and 2 the law then in force would govern the succession. Now if this proposition is correct, as we hold it is, that where a female heir succeeds to an estate, the person entitled to succeed on the basis as if the last male holder had lived up to and died at the Mt.
